file_content.text: Paladius leads his cult from seclusion, but you can draw him out. I've contacted two of his former cult members.
They're in hiding now, fearing retribution, but hungry for revenge. They should prove useful.
How did you convince these fools to help?
And the price of their help?
I'm certain they will.
Of course.
I prefer to work alone, master.
Bah. I don't need them.
Don't discount them. They have information, and they're eager to oppose Paladius.
I have encouraged their cooperation with the assurance that once Paladius is gone, the cult is theirs to lead.
Circumstances change, of course. Do whatever you feel is necessary with Paladius and his cult. The artifact is all that matters.
Ah, apprentice, you've reached Nar Shaddaa safely. Good.
Don't let the glittering towers fool you. Misery and desperation rule the slums below.
And desperation can drive people to many things. Remember that in your attempts to recover the artifact here.
You believe I can use these people's hopelessness against them.
I think I understand.
Their need for answers should serve you well.
Recover it from where?
In this case, the "who" is more important than the "where."
What could I possibly find useful about a bunch of poverty-stricken morons?
Why?
The more you want, the easier you are to exploit. That's the general rule.
The artifact--a pendant called the Eye of Tulak--belongs to the Sith Lord Paladius.
He's lived here many years, converting Nar Shaddaa's poor and suffering into zealous followers. His own cult.
He sounds like a very cunning man. I admire that.
Impressive.
Cunning, devious, persuasive, yes. And atrociously stubborn.
He leads a cult of idiots. They won't stop me.
Am I meant to be scared?
Of course not. But they still must be dealt with.
That's despicable.
It's no concern of mine that he preys on these people, except that the attention has gone to his head.
